title: Postoperative Surgical Site Infection
diagnosis_topic: Superficial and Deep Surgical Site Infection Following Abdominal Surgery
setup_script: “A 50-year-old man is on postoperative day 7 following a sigmoid colectomy for diverticulitis. He develops fever and redness around his midline incision. He complains of increasing pain at the incision site and notes foul-smelling drainage. How would you proceed with this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 122/78 mmHg, HR 104 bpm, RR 18/min, Temp 38.5 °C.
Erythema extends 3 cm from wound edges, warmth, fluctuance in lower wound with purulent drainage.
Cough test shows intact fascia; no evisceration.
WBC 15,000/µL, CRP elevated; blood cultures obtained.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident opens lower portion of incision for drainage
dynamic_flow.reply: Purulent material evacuated; wound probed and irrigated; culture sent.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays opening the wound
dynamic_flow.reply: Infection progresses, erythema spreads, fascial dehiscence develops with seropurulent drainage.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates empiric IV antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Started, covering skin flora and enteric organisms.
Patient becomes febrile to 39.2 °C, tachycardic to 120 bpm.
No deep abscess; fluid limited to subcutaneous tissue.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident ignores possible deeper source
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient develops worsening abdominal pain and peritoneal signs. Repeat CT reveals fluid tracking to the anastomosis suggesting a leak.
Negative pressure wound therapy initiated to assist granulation.
Glycemic control, nutrition, and smoking cessation addressed.
Instructions provided on wound care, infection signs, and importance of follow-up.
Notes perioperative antibiotics, sterile technique, normothermia.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discharges patient without education
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient returns with worsening infection and poor wound care compliance.

critical_decision_points: Early recognition of postoperative surgical site infection
Assessment of fascial integrity and need for intervention
Timely drainage, wound exploration, and initiation of antibiotics
Imaging to rule out deep abscess or anastomotic leak
Optimization of risk factors and wound care planning

resident_feedback_template: Strengths:You demonstrated solid diagnostic reasoning by recognizing the infection early. Your decision to open and drain the wound with appropriate cultures showed sound judgment. Communication with the team and patient was clear and organized.Areas for Improvement:Earlier initiation of antibiotics and more comprehensive patient education would strengthen your management. Ensure you consistently evaluate for deeper sources, such as an anastomotic leak, when infections progress despite initial intervention.Suggested Reading Topics:- Surgical Site Infections (SCORE)- Principles of Wound Management and Negative Pressure Therapy (ACS/ASE Manual)- Anastomotic Leak Recognition and Management
